Will Elon Musk be the richest person in the world at any point during the 2020s?
Sam Bankman-Fried is currently the richest person in crypto as well as the richest person under 30. He plans on donating the majority of his wealth to effective charities.

Q.title: Will Elon Musk be the richest person in the world on December 31, 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Elon Musk is the world's richest person according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index on December 31, 2025.
If the Bloomberg Billionaires Index is no longer published, the Forbes Real Time Billionaires list should be used. If neither list is published, this will resolve according to the source identified by a consensus of Metaculus moderators; if there is no clear consensus, then the question will resolve as Ambiguous

metadata.background_info:
Elon Musk is the founder and/or CEO of several companies, including electric vehicle company Tesla, space exploration and nascent Internet provider company SpaceX, tunneling company The Boring Company, and brain interface company Neuralink. He is currently the third richest person in the world, with a net worth of $167 billion, according to Bloomberg Billionaires Index.
He was briefly the richest person in the world in early 2021.

R.title: Will the S&P 500 rise or fall more than 15% in a single day during the 2020s?
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if before January 1st 2030 and after January 1st 2020, the S&P 500 moves by more than 15.0% from opening to closing price, in a single day

metadata.background_info: The S&P 500 is often used as a benchmark for the performance of large-cap companies in the United States. On October 19, 1987 (so-called Black Monday), the S&P fell 20.47%, the largest movement in its history, which has yet to be surpassed. Generally, when the stock market makes a sudden move, it indicates that there has been some economic shock, such as when the S&P 500 fell 11.98% during the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic.

reasons: The wealth of individuals like Sam Bankman-Fried and Elon Musk can be influenced by the performance of the stock market, including indices like the S&P 500. A significant rise or fall in the S&P 500 could impact their net worth, especially if they have substantial investments in the stock market.

The financial strategies and business decisions of individuals like Sam Bankman-Fried and Elon Musk might be influenced by major market movements. For example, a significant drop in the S&P 500 might lead to strategic shifts in their companies, which could affect their personal wealth.

Market volatility, as indicated by a significant movement in the S&P 500, could create opportunities or challenges for major investors and entrepreneurs, potentially affecting their ranking among the world's richest individuals.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as the performance of the S&P 500 could impact the wealth of Sam Bankman-Fried and Elon Musk.

P.title: Will Stacey Abrams be elected president in or before the 2040 election?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This resolves positively if Stacey Abrams is elected president in or before 2040 and the result is not overturned prior to inauguration, whether or not she is actually inaugurated. This resolves negatively by any other outcome

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on Stacey Abrams being elected president in or before the 2040 election, will the federal minimum wage increase in the United States before 2025?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P:
This resolves positively if Stacey Abrams is elected president in or before 2040 and the result is not overturned prior to inauguration, whether or not she is actually inaugurated. This resolves negatively by any other outcome.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
The federal minimum wage in the United States is currently $7.25 an hour, and was most recently changed in 2009.
This question resolves positively if at least three reliable media outlets report that the federal minimum wage increased from $7.25 any time before January 1st 2025. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
This question can be resolved at any time.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Conditional on Stacey Abrams being elected president in or before the 2040 election and the federal minimum wage increasing in the United States before 2025, will Starlink set a record for the largest IPO before 2030?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Suppose the following is true: Stacey Abrams is elected president in or before the 2040 election and the federal minimum wage increases in the United States before 2025. Then, if Starlink offers an IPO before 2030, will it set a record for the largest IPO?

Resolution Criteria for P:
(a) Stacey Abrams is elected president in or before 2040 and the result is not overturned prior to inauguration, whether or not she is actually inaugurated.
(b) At least three reliable media outlets report that the federal minimum wage increased from $7.25 any time before January 1st 2025.
This resolves negatively if either or both of the above conditions are not met.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
This claim will be judged according to reports in The Wall Street Journal, New York Times, Financial Times, Bloomberg press sources. If any of them report a Starlink IPO which exceeds that of Saudi Aramco and any additional IPO's that occur between 2020 and the date of a Starlink IPO. If there is no Starlink IPO prior to 2030-01-01 this question will resolve ambiguously. Comparisons of IPO amounts will be adjusted for inflation.

P_and_Q_and_R.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Stacey Abrams is elected president in or before the 2040 election and the federal minimum wage increases in the United States before 2025, and (b) If Starlink offers an IPO before 2030, it sets a record for the largest IPO?
P_and_Q_and_R.body:
Resolution Criteria
This resolves positively if all of the following occur:
(a) Stacey Abrams is elected president in or before 2040 and the result is not overturned prior to inauguration, whether or not she is actually inaugurated.
(b) At least three reliable media outlets report that the federal minimum wage increased from $7.25 any time before January 1st 2025.
(c) If Starlink offers an IPO before 2030, it sets a record for the largest IPO according to reports in The Wall Street Journal, New York Times, Financial Times, Bloomberg press sources. The IPO must exceed that of Saudi Aramco and any additional IPO's that occur between 2020 and the date of a Starlink IPO, adjusted for inflation.
This resolves negatively if any of the above conditions are not met.

P.title: Will Stacey Abrams be elected president in or before the 2040 election?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This resolves positively if Stacey Abrams is elected president in or before 2040 and the result is not overturned prior to inauguration, whether or not she is actually inaugurated. This resolves negatively by any other outcome

metadata.background_info:

Source: Stacey Abrams Thinks She’ll Be President By 2040

Q.title: Will the federal minimum wage increase in the United States before 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The federal minimum wage in the United States is currently $7.25 an hour, and was most recently changed in 2009.
This question resolves positively if at least three reliable media outlets report that the federal minimum wage increased from $7.25 any time before January 1st 2025. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
This question can be resolved at any time.

R.title: If Starlink offers an IPO before 2030, will it set a record for the largest IPO?
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
related question on Metaculus:
Will Starlink conduct an IPO before 2030?
Elon Musk has been speaking openly about a possible Starlink IPO. The largest IPO's as of 2020 include Saudi Aramco, which raised $30 Billion.
Will Starlink set a record for the largest IPO before 2030?
This claim will be judged according to reports in The Wall Street Journal, New York Times, Financial Times, Bloomberg press sources. If any of them report a Starlink IPO which exceeds that of Saudi Aramco and any additional IPO's that occur between 2020 and the date of a Starlink IPO
If there is no Starlink IPO prior to 2030-01-01 this question will resolve ambiguously.
Comparisons of IPO amounts will be adjusted for inflation.

reasons: Stacey Abrams being elected president could indicate a shift in political climate that might also affect economic policies, including the federal minimum wage.

A change in the federal minimum wage could be indicative of broader economic trends that might influence investor confidence and market conditions, potentially affecting the success of an IPO like Starlink's.

The political and economic environment under a new administration, such as one led by Stacey Abrams, could impact regulatory and market conditions, which in turn could influence the size and success of major IPOs.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as they all involve significant political and economic changes that could be interrelated.

P.title: If there's a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, will this cause >400 million fatalities?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, using the same specification as in a previous question (except that here the year 2030 is used instead of 2024[1]). That is, the question resolves ambiguously if that condition isn't met. As noted in that previous question, this could be caused either by nuclear conflict or by something else.
The question resolves positively if:
The above condition is met
At least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall.
For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032.
If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
See also:
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >100m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations cause >4b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Fine Print
For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the 10% shortfall. For example, if the 10% shortfall is followed by armed conflict, no attempt will be made to second-guess what credible sources say about whether the fatalities caused by that armed conflict should be considered to be ultimately caused by the 10% shortfall.
[1] The reason for using 2030 rather than 2024 for this question is that the fatalities and discussion of them may occur on a several-year delay from the actual shortfall. It therefore seemed unwise to force this question to resolve by 2024, and hence best to make this part of the long-term rather than calibration tournament.

Q_given_P.title: If there's a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, will any state refuse to certify their election results in the 2024 US presidential election?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for the condition:
This question conditions on there being a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, using the same specification as in a previous question (except that here the year 2030 is used instead of 2024). That is, the question resolves ambiguously if that condition isn't met. As noted in that previous question, this could be caused either by nuclear conflict or by something else.
The question resolves positively if:
The above condition is met
At least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall.
For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032.
If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the 10% shortfall. For example, if the 10% shortfall is followed by armed conflict, no attempt will be made to second-guess what credible sources say about whether the fatalities caused by that armed conflict should be considered to be ultimately caused by the 10% shortfall.

Resolution Criteria for the outcome:
The question will resolve positively if any state (or DC) does not certify their results by the "safe harbor" deadline. The "safe harbor" deadline for the 2024 presidential election will be December 10th.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Conditional on both a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 causing >400 million fatalities and any state refusing to certify their election results in the 2024 US presidential election, will the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in colleges in 2025 be ≥10% less than were enrolled in 2015?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for P:
(a) There is a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, using the same specification as in a previous question (except that here the year 2030 is used instead of 2024). This could be caused either by nuclear conflict or by something else. The question resolves ambiguously if that condition isn't met. The question resolves positively if at least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall. For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032. If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate. For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the 10% shortfall. For example, if the 10% shortfall is followed by armed conflict, no attempt will be made to second-guess what credible sources say about whether the fatalities caused by that armed conflict should be considered to be ultimately caused by the 10% shortfall.
(b) In the 2024 US presidential election, any state (or DC) does not certify their results by the "safe harbor" deadline. The "safe harbor" deadline for the 2024 presidential election will be December 10th.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
In the US, enrollment in 4-year colleges has been steadily increasing since the 1970s, from around 17.1% to 29.9% in 2015.
Despite this, the economist Bryan Caplan has recently argued that this time spent in college by an increasing proportion of youth is wasteful, as the primary function of education is not to enhance students' skill but to certify their intelligence, work ethic, and conformity — in other words, to signal the qualities of a good employee.
As increasing numbers of students get more degrees, the harder it becomes to remain competitive in the job market without spending lots of time in education — essentially creating a prisoner's dilemma in which it is individually rational, but socially harmful to waste evermore time getting degrees. This has made some confident that educational enrolment will only increase over time, including the aforementioned economist who has been placing bets on this.
Will the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in traditional four-year colleges in 2025 be more than 10% lower than in 2015?
Since the 2015 rate is 29.9%, positive resolution is conditional on a rate 26.91% or less in 2025 as reported by data from the National Center for Education Statistics.
If both conditions in P are met, will the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in traditional four-year colleges in 2025 be more than 10% lower than in 2015?

P_and_Q_and_R.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) If there's a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, will this cause >400 million fatalities? (b) In the 2024 US presidential election, will any state refuse to certify their election results?
P_and_Q_and_R.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if both of the following conditions are met:
(a) There is a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030, using the same specification as in a previous question (except that here the year 2030 is used instead of 2024). This could be caused either by nuclear conflict or by something else. The question resolves ambiguously if that condition isn't met. The question resolves positively if at least three credible sources state or estimate that, within 5 years of the end of the year in which the first 10% shortfall by 2030 occurs, more than 400 million fatalities were caused by that shortfall. For example, if the shortfall occurs in 2027, this question is about whether that causes >400m fatalities by the end of 2032. If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate. For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the 10% shortfall. For example, if the 10% shortfall is followed by armed conflict, no attempt will be made to second-guess what credible sources say about whether the fatalities caused by that armed conflict should be considered to be ultimately caused by the 10% shortfall.
(b) In the 2024 US presidential election, any state (or DC) does not certify their results by the "safe harbor" deadline. The "safe harbor" deadline for the 2024 presidential election will be December 10th.
(c) The fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in traditional four-year colleges in 2025 is more than 10% lower than in 2015. Since the 2015 rate is 29.9%, positive resolution is conditional on a rate 26.91% or less in 2025 as reported by data from the National Center for Education Statistics.

If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
See also:
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >100m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >1b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations cause >4b fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation?
Fine Print
For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the 10% shortfall. For example, if the 10% shortfall is followed by armed conflict, no attempt will be made to second-guess what credible sources say about whether the fatalities caused by that armed conflict should be considered to be ultimately caused by the 10% shortfall.

metadata.background_info:
Another question in this tournament asks Will there be a 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2024?.
Denkenberger & Pearce (2016) write:
"The uncertainty in the number of fatalities due to a 10% agricultural shortfall is very large. On the optimistic extreme, there could be aggressive government support or charity such that the vast majority of the global poor could generally afford sufficient food. If the crisis were only a year or two, loans could be feasible, either to poor individuals or poor countries. The necessary conservation (less waste, less food to animals, and so on) in the developed countries could be achieved by higher prices or rationing. However, even if mass starvation is averted, generally there would be more malnutrition and increasing susceptibility to disease. The poor would be less able to afford other lifesaving measures, and a pandemic would be more likely. Even if food aid is available, it may not be possible to get the food to the people who need it. Therefore, near zero mortality is unlikely. At the same time, even with no catastrophe, 6.5 million people die of hunger-related diseases per year (UNICEF 2006). On the other extreme, there could be food export restrictions or bans, as implemented by India, Vietnam, Egypt, and China in 2008 (Helfand 2013) when the situation was much less serious. This hoarding on a country level could also be coupled with hoarding on an individual level. This could dramatically reduce the food supply available to poor people.
Armed conflict could be in some countries’ best interest, which could also aggravate famine (Keller 1992; Waldman 2001; Goodhand 2003). These wars could even evolve into nuclear conflict, which would further impact food supplies."

Q.title: In the 2024 US presidential election, will any state refuse to certify their election results?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve positively if any state (or DC) does not certify their results by the "safe harbor" deadline. The "safe harbor" deadline for the 2024 presidential election will be December 10th

metadata.background_info:
Recent controversy over state election laws has caused some Democrats to be concerned that Republicans intend to use their political power in state governments to distort future elections in their favor. One commentator recently suggested:
"If a Democrat wins a GOP-controlled swing state in 2024 … there’s a very good chance the victory isn’t certified"
Election certification is the process in which states confirm the election results and declare them to be the official results. Typically states set their own deadlines for election certification, which in 2020 ranged from November 5th to December 8th for the presidential contest (several states appear to have no deadline), but federal law provides a "safe harbor" deadline by which states must formally certify their election results in order for the certified results to be federally recognized as governing the outcome. The "safe harbor" deadline is set by 3 U.S. Code § 5 and 3 U.S. Code § 7 which sets the safe harbor deadline as six days prior to the first Monday after the second Wednesday in December of the election year.

R.title: Will the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in colleges in 2025 be ≥10% less than were enrolled in 2015?
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
In the US, enrollment in 4-year colleges has been steadily increasing since the 1970s, from around 17.1% to 29.9% in 2015.
Despite this, the economist Bryan Caplan has recently argued that this time spent in college by an increasing proportion of youth is wasteful, as the primary function of education is not to enhance students' skill but to certify their intelligence, work ethic, and conformity — in other words, to signal the qualities of a good employee.
As increasing numbers of students get more degrees, the harder it becomes to remain competitive in the job market without spending lots of time in education — essentially creating a prisoner's dilemma in which it is individually rational, but socially harmful to waste evermore time getting degrees. This has made some confident that educational enrolment will only increase over time, including the aforementioned economist who has been placing bets on this.
Will the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in traditional four-year colleges in 2025 be more than 10% lower than in 2015?
Since the 2015 rate is 29.9%, positive resolution is conditional on a rate 26.91% or less in 2025 as reported by data from the National Center for Education Statistics.

reasons: A 10% global agricultural shortfall by 2030 could lead to significant economic and social instability, which might influence political actions and decisions, including those related to election certifications.

Economic and social instability caused by a global agricultural shortfall could also impact educational enrollment rates, as families might prioritize immediate economic survival over long-term educational investments.
Political instability, such as states refusing to certify election results, could further exacerbate economic and social instability, potentially influencing educational enrollment rates.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as they all relate to potential large-scale disruptions and their cascading effects on society.

P.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech regarding the ramifications of this particular AI development, within two weeks of the initial news reports.
The Nasdaq Composite (which is currently heavily weighted towards companies in the information technology sector) rises over 30% in the course of a single week, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock prices is likely a result of the AI development.
The Google Trends monitor for artificial intelligence shows that interest in artificial intelligence rises by over 100% relative to of its previous value, compared to the week prior (using the resolution at 12 months, as currently displayed by the Google Trends widget). If Google Trends changes their functionality or methodology dramatically (as determined by Metaculus admins), then this condition can no longer trigger a positive resolution.
Practically all reliable media outlets are referring to an AI development as an AI Sputnik moment, as referring to the historical Sputnik 1 satellite
Fine Print
Google Trends index scores vary depending on the date and location from which a user checks the site. To reduce ambiguity, to trigger the Google Trends section of the resolution criteria:
At least two Metaculus administrators need to be able to see the >100% Google Trends increase, when checking from different locations.
The increase must remain >100% for at least four days to trigger a Yes resolution. For instance, if we first notice an increase of >100% on a Monday, we will check again on Friday. We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

metadata.background_info:
From Wikipedia,
Sputnik 1 was the first artificial Earth satellite. It was launched into an elliptical low Earth orbit by the USSR on 4 October 1957 as part of the Soviet space program. It orbited for three weeks before its batteries died and then orbited silently for two months before it fell back into the atmosphere on the 4th January 1958.
[...]
The satellite's unanticipated success precipitated the American Sputnik crisis and triggered the Space Race, part of the Cold War. The launch was the beginning of a new era of political, military, technological and scientific developments.
An "AI Sputnik moment" would, by contrast, be a sudden understanding by the general public that artificial intelligence is worth taking extremely seriously, perhaps triggering a similar AI arms race.

Q.title: Will there be a Nobel Prize in Physics awarded for work in string theory before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if a Nobel Prize in Physics is widely considered by credible media to have been awarded to someone for their work on string theory before 2050

metadata.background_info:
String theory
roughly speaking, replaces point particles by strings, which can be either open or closed (depends on the particular type of particle that is being replaced by the string), whose length, or string length, is approximately 10^(−33) cm. Also, in string theory, one replaces Feynman diagrams by surfaces, and wordlines become worldsheets.
In late 2019 John Horgan won a 2002 longbets.com bet with physicist Michio Kaku that by 2020 no unified theory of physics will win a Nobel Prize.

R.title: Will a Democrat win the 2024 US presidential election?
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a candidate from the Democratic Party receives the most votes in the Electoral College in the 2024 US Presidential Election. It will resolve on the date Congress certifies the votes, or when Congress selects the President in the case a candidate does not receive a majority.

metadata.background_info:
Every 4 years, the United States elects a president with its unique system of the Electoral College. A candidate must secure 270 or more electoral college votes out of 538, or be selected by Congress if no candidate receives more than 269 votes.
The 2020 election ended with President Donald Trump losing his run for a second term. He immediately and repeatedly made claims the election was rigged and fraudulent, which led to the January 6 storming of the Capitol. Ultimately, the votes were confirmed by Congress and Joe Biden was inaugurated on January 20, 2021.
Biden faces several challenges entering his presidency, including the COVID-19 pandemic and an unemployment rate of 6.7%, with a narrow majority in Congress to pass legislation. Biden began his presidency with a historically high disapproval rating of 35%, indicating that we are in a period of high partisanship and highly competitive elections. On the other hand, politicians generally have an incumbency advantage, which could mean a likely victory for Biden.

reasons: An AI Sputnik moment could have significant geopolitical and economic ramifications, which might influence the political landscape in the US, potentially affecting the 2024 presidential election outcome.
A major AI breakthrough could also impact scientific research funding and priorities, possibly influencing the likelihood of a Nobel Prize in Physics being awarded for work in string theory.
The election of a Democrat in 2024 could lead to different policies regarding AI research and development, which might affect the likelihood of an AI Sputnik moment occurring before 2050.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as they are interconnected through potential impacts on politics, economics, and scientific research.

P.title: Will NASA return a sample of material from the surface of Mars to Earth before SpaceX Starship lands on Mars?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The resolution of this question depends on the relative timing of two events:
1) A mission substantially (>30%) or wholly funded by NASA successfully returns a sample from the surface of Mars to Earth.
2) A rocket build by SpaceX designated as "Starship" or clearly designated as a successor to Starship successfully lands on Mars.
The question will resolve positive if event 1) happens before event 2).
The question will resolve negatively if event 2) happens before event 1).
If neither of these events happens before the closing date (2035) the question will resolve ambiguously.
Note that the following series of events would result in a negative resolution: SpaceX builds a Starship rocket which is purchased by NASA. That rocket lands on Mars successfully. That rocket returns to Earth with samples from Mars in it. Because the SpaceX Starship landed on Mars before the NASA mission returned samples to Earth, the question resolves negative.
Similarly, the following sequence of events would resolve positive: NASA contracts a Falcon Heavy from SpaceX for one of its missions. That mission successfully returns samples to Earth before Starship lands on earth.
It is also worth noting that if both NASA and SpaceX hew to their currently claimed timelines, Starship will land on Mars in 2026, 4 years before a sample return mission is completed in 2030

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on NASA returning a sample of material from the surface of Mars to Earth before SpaceX Starship lands on Mars, will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P:
The resolution of this question depends on the relative timing of two events:
1) A mission substantially (>30%) or wholly funded by NASA successfully returns a sample from the surface of Mars to Earth.
2) A rocket built by SpaceX designated as "Starship" or clearly designated as a successor to Starship successfully lands on Mars.
The question will resolve positively if event 1) happens before event 2).
The question will resolve negatively if event 2) happens before event 1).
If neither of these events happens before the closing date (2035) the question will resolve ambiguously.
Note that the following series of events would result in a negative resolution: SpaceX builds a Starship rocket which is purchased by NASA. That rocket lands on Mars successfully. That rocket returns to Earth with samples from Mars in it. Because the SpaceX Starship landed on Mars before the NASA mission returned samples to Earth, the question resolves negative.
Similarly, the following sequence of events would resolve positive: NASA contracts a Falcon Heavy from SpaceX for one of its missions. That mission successfully returns samples to Earth before Starship lands on Mars.
It is also worth noting that if both NASA and SpaceX hew to their currently claimed timelines, Starship will land on Mars in 2026, 4 years before a sample return mission is completed in 2030.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
Currently, artificial intelligence can outperform humans in a number of narrow domains, such as playing chess and searching data. As artificial intelligence researchers continue to make progress, though, these domains are highly likely to grow in number and breadth over time. Many experts now believe there is a significant chance that a machine superintelligence – a system that can outperform humans at all relevant intelligence tasks – will be developed within the next century, and possibly much sooner.
As predictions to a previous question suggest, artificial intelligence might pose a global catastrophic risk (defined there as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years). When considering how AI might become a risk, experts think two scenarios most likely, according to the Future of Life Institute:
The AI is programmed to do something devastating: Autonomous weapons are artificial intelligence systems that are programmed to kill. In the hands of the wrong person, these weapons could easily cause mass casualties. Moreover, an AI arms race could inadvertently lead to an AI war that also results in mass casualties. To avoid being thwarted by the enemy, these weapons would be designed to be extremely difficult to simply “turn off,” so humans could plausibly lose control of such a situation. This risk is one that’s present even with narrow AI, but grows as levels of AI intelligence and autonomy increase.
The AI is programmed to do something beneficial, but it develops a destructive method for achieving its goal: This can happen whenever we fail to fully align the AI’s goals with ours, which is strikingly difficult. If you ask an obedient intelligent car to take you to the airport as fast as possible, it might get you there chased by helicopters and covered in vomit, doing not what you wanted but literally what you asked for. If a superintelligent system is tasked with an ambitious geoengineering project, it might wreak havoc with our ecosystem as a side effect, and view human attempts to stop it as a threat to be met. As these examples illustrate, the concern about advanced AI isn’t malevolence but competence. A super-intelligent AI will be extremely good at accomplishing its goals, and if those goals aren’t aligned with ours, we have a problem.
It is thought by some that reducing the second of these two risks will require progress in technical methods of developing scalable control methods that could ensure that a AI will be safe and will behave as its programmers intend even if its intellectual capabilities are increased to arbitrary levels. Until recently, this problem was almost entirely neglected; but in the last couple of years, technical research agendas have been developed, and there are now several research groups pursuing work in this area. Total investment in long-term AI safety, however, remains orders of magnitude less than investment in increasing AI capability. Additionally, reducing the first of the listed risks might require improvements in our ability to control, govern and coordinate on the usage of such systems, so to reduce potential security threats from malicious uses of AI technologies.
But how certain are we that artificial intelligence continue to be regarded to constitute a large chunk of global catastrophic risk, at least through 2040? A previous question asked: If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of some Artificial Intelligence system(s)?
Will the probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remain above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040?
This question resolves positively if both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fail to fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Conditional on NASA returning a sample from Mars before SpaceX Starship lands on Mars and Metaculus predicting AI poses a global catastrophic risk by 2040, will Climeworks still exist in 2030?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for P:
1) A mission substantially (>30%) or wholly funded by NASA successfully returns a sample from the surface of Mars to Earth before a rocket built by SpaceX designated as "Starship" or clearly designated as a successor to Starship successfully lands on Mars. The question will resolve positively if this event happens before the other. The question will resolve negatively if the other event happens before this one. If neither of these events happens before the closing date (2035), the question will resolve ambiguously.
2) The probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years) remains above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040. This will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins. The question resolves positively if both the Metaculus and community predictions of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fail to fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040.

This combined question will resolve positively only if both of the above events occur as specified.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
Stripe, a financial-services company, committed last year to spending at least $1M/year on negative emissions and carbon storage technologies, at any price, with the aim of helping these technologies develop.
They recently wrote up a summary of their first set of these purchases.
This miniseries aims to predict the success of the companies that Stripe chose.
Stripe has purchased 322.5 tons of negative emissions from Climeworks at $775 per ton.
Climeworks uses renewable geothermal energy and waste heat to capture CO2 directly from the air, concentrate it, and permanently sequester it underground in basaltic rock formations with Carbfix. Their own price target in the long-term is $100-$200 per ton.
This question asks:
On 2030/7/1, will Climeworks still be selling negative emissions using broadly similar technology to their 2020 approach?
This question resolves positive if this question has an unambiguous resolution. Otherwise, it resolves negative.

P_and_Q_and_R.title: Will NASA return a sample of material from the surface of Mars to Earth before SpaceX Starship lands on Mars, will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040, and will Climeworks still exist in 2030?
P_and_Q_and_R.body:
Resolution Criteria
The resolution of this question depends on the occurrence of the following three events:
1) A mission substantially (>30%) or wholly funded by NASA successfully returns a sample from the surface of Mars to Earth before a rocket built by SpaceX designated as "Starship" or clearly designated as a successor to Starship successfully lands on Mars. The question will resolve positively if this event happens before the other. The question will resolve negatively if the other event happens before this one. If neither of these events happens before the closing date (2035), the question will resolve ambiguously.
2) The probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years) remains above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040. This will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins. The question resolves positively if both the Metaculus and community predictions of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fail to fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040.
3) On 2030/7/1, Climeworks will still be selling negative emissions using broadly similar technology to their 2020 approach. This question resolves positive if this question has an unambiguous resolution. Otherwise, it resolves negative.

This combined question will resolve positively only if all of the above events occur as specified.

metadata.background_info:
NASA's first successful lander was the Viking 1 lander in 1975. Since then, NASA's missions to Mars have increased in number and complexity. While NASA's stated ultimate objective is bringing humans to Mars and back, an intermediate goal is that of sample-return, bringing a sample of material from the surface of Mars back to Earth. Given a 2-year trip each way, a mission tenatively planned to launch in 2026 would return samples to Earth around 2030.
SpaceX has been working on its own "Mars" program, the Starship. Elon Musk has claimed that the Starship may launch for Mars as soon as 2024. Such a mission would land on Mars in 2026.

The AI is programmed to do something beneficial, but it develops a destructive method for achieving its goal: This can happen whenever we fail to fully align the AI’s goals with ours, which is strikingly difficult. If you ask an obedient intelligent car to take you to the airport as fast as possible, it might get you there chased by helicopters and covered in vomit, doing not what you wanted but literally what you asked for. If a superintelligent system is tasked with a ambitious geoengineering project, it might wreak havoc with our ecosystem as a side effect, and view human attempts to stop it as a threat to be met. As these examples illustrate, the concern about advanced AI isn’t malevolence but competence. A super-intelligent AI will be extremely good at accomplishing its goals, and if those goals aren’t aligned with ours, we have a problem.
It is thought by some that reducing the second of these two risks will require progress in technical methods of developing scalable control methods that could ensure that a AI will be safe and will behave as its programmers intend even if its intellectual capabilities are increased to arbitrary levels. Until recently, this problem was almost entirely neglected; but in the last couple of years, technical research agendas have been developed, and there are now several research groups pursuing work in this area. Total investment in long-term AI safety, however, remains orders of magnitude less than investment in increasing AI capability. Additionally, reducing the first of the listed risks might require improvements in our ability to control, govern and coordinate on the usage of such systems, so to reduce potential security threats from malicious uses of AI technologies.
But how certain are we that artificial intelligence continue to be regarded to constitute a large chunk of global catastrophic risk, at least through 2040? A previous question asked: If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of some Artificial Intelligence system(s)?
Will the probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remain above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040?
This question resolves positively if both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fail to fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins.

R.title: Will Climeworks still exist in 2030?
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
Stripe, a financial-services company, committed last year to spending at least $1M/year on negative emissions and carbon storage technologies, at any price, with the aim of helping these technologies develop.
They recently wrote up a summary of their first set of these purchases.
This miniseries aims to predict the success of the companies that Stripe chose.
Stripe has purchased 322.5 tons of negative emissions from Climeworks at $775 per ton.
Climeworks uses renewable geothermal energy and waste heat to capture CO2 directly from the air, concentrate it, and permanently sequester it underground in basaltic rock formations with Carbfix. Their own price target in the long-term is $100-$200 per ton.
This question asks:
On 2030/7/1, will Climeworks still be selling negative emissions using broadly similar technology to their 2020 approach?
This question resolves positive if this question has an unambiguous resolution. Otherwise, it resolves negative.

reasons: The first question involves significant technological and organizational milestones for NASA and SpaceX, which are major players in space exploration. The outcome of this question could influence public and private investment in space technology, which might indirectly affect other technological sectors, including AI and climate tech.

The second question is about the perceived risk of AI, which is a topic of global concern. The development and regulation of AI could be influenced by broader technological trends and geopolitical factors, which might also impact space exploration and climate tech.

The third question involves Climeworks, a company working on carbon capture technology. The success or failure of such companies could be influenced by broader technological and economic trends, including those in space exploration and AI.

All three questions are related to significant technological advancements and their potential impacts on society. The logical combination of these questions could provide insights into how different technological trends might interact and influence each other over the next decade.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions makes sense as they all involve significant technological advancements and their potential impacts on society. The combination could provide valuable insights into how different technological trends might interact and influence each other.

P.title: Will there be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory
Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway

Q_given_P.title: Given a global thermonuclear war by 2070, will a Starlink IPO before 2030 set a record for the largest IPO?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: There is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
1. Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
2. Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.

These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.

Then, if Starlink offers an IPO before 2030, will it set a record for the largest IPO?

Resolution Criteria for the IPO:
Elon Musk has been speaking openly about a possible Starlink IPO. The largest IPO's as of 2020 include Saudi Aramco, which raised $30 Billion. This claim will be judged according to reports in The Wall Street Journal, New York Times, Financial Times, Bloomberg press sources. If any of them report a Starlink IPO which exceeds that of Saudi Aramco and any additional IPO's that occur between 2020 and the date of a Starlink IPO. Comparisons of IPO amounts will be adjusted for inflation.

If there is no Starlink IPO prior to 2030-01-01 this question will resolve ambiguously.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Conditional on a global thermonuclear war by 2070 and Starlink setting a record IPO before 2030, will there be any progress in human lifespan enhancement by 2100?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for P:
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met:
1. There is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
   a. Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
   b. Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
2. If Starlink offers an IPO before 2030, it sets a record for the largest IPO. This will be judged according to reports in The Wall Street Journal, New York Times, Financial Times, Bloomberg press sources. If any of them report a Starlink IPO which exceeds that of Saudi Aramco and any additional IPO's that occur between 2020 and the date of a Starlink IPO. Comparisons of IPO amounts will be adjusted for inflation.

If there is no Starlink IPO prior to 2030-01-01, this question will resolve ambiguously.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occur before January 1, 2100:
At least 10 people have confirmed lifespans of at least 130 years of age
At least 100 people have confirmed lifespans of at least 120 years of age
Ray Kurzweil lives to the age of 120
The verification process on these individuals' lifespans should be at least as strict as the standards used during 2018. People resuscitated after being cryonically frozen will not be included in this question's resolution

P_and_Q_and_R.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if all of the following conditions are met:
1. There is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
   a. Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
   b. Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
2. If Starlink offers an IPO before 2030, it sets a record for the largest IPO. This will be judged according to reports in The Wall Street Journal, New York Times, Financial Times, Bloomberg press sources. If any of them report a Starlink IPO which exceeds that of Saudi Aramco and any additional IPO's that occur between 2020 and the date of a Starlink IPO. Comparisons of IPO amounts will be adjusted for inflation.
3. Any of the following occur before January 1, 2100:
   a. At least 10 people have confirmed lifespans of at least 130 years of age.
   b. At least 100 people have confirmed lifespans of at least 120 years of age.
   c. Ray Kurzweil lives to the age of 120.
The verification process on these individuals' lifespans should be at least as strict as the standards used during 2018. People resuscitated after being cryonically frozen will not be included in this question's resolution.

If there is no Starlink IPO prior to 2030-01-01, this question will resolve ambiguously.

Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:

Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.

metadata.background_info:
Weapons in which the energy is provided by nuclear fission or fusion have only twice in history been detonated outside of a controlled test environment, in the Hiroshima and Nagasaki events in World War II.
Since then, the world has nearly gone to nuclear war as a result of international conflict (during the Cuban Missile Crisis) and by accident. (Indeed, there have been a number of narrowly-averted accidental nuclear detonations. See this timeline for a sobering look at how close we have come.)
This question (which any sane person will hope resolves negatively) regards the probability that a nuclear war will occur by Jan 1, 2070. (Different questions address this separately, but none directly.) There is a great paucity of public and useful estimates of this probability. See for example this paper for an outline of considerations (but no bottom-line numbers.)

Q.title: If Starlink offers an IPO before 2030, will it set a record for the largest IPO?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
related question on Metaculus:
Will Starlink conduct an IPO before 2030?
Elon Musk has been speaking openly about a possible Starlink IPO. The largest IPO's as of 2020 include Saudi Aramco, which raised $30 Billion.
Will Starlink set a record for the largest IPO before 2030?

Comparisons of IPO amounts will be adjusted for inflation.

R.title: Will there be any progress in human lifespan enhancement by 2100?
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occur before January 1, 2100:
At least 10 people have confirmed lifespans of at least 130 years of age
At least 100 people have confirmed lifespans of at least 120 years of age
Ray Kurzweil lives to the age of 120
The verification process on these individuals' lifespans should be at least as strict as the standards used during 2018. People resuscitated after being cryonically frozen will not be included in this question's resolution

metadata.background_info:
There have been great improvements in medical technology in the last few centuries, which has led to very significant increases in life expectancy. Yet, while medical technology has stopped the vast majority of us dying young, it has not been very effective at increasing the maximum age that humans can live to. Ramesses II lived to the age of 90, even though the life expectancy in ancient Egypt might have been below 30. Similarly, the English aristocracy between 1500-1550 already had a life expectancy of 71, meaning that quite a few of them will have lived into their 80s. The oldest person the world, as of the writing of this question, is aged 117. It is unclear whether anybody in the ancient world lived to a similar age (there were many claims of extreme age and very poor record keeping), but it certainly does not seem completely impossible.
Recently, though, there have been attempts to actually extend he upper limit of human lifespan. The Methuselah Foundation has managed to keep mice alive for the equivalent of 180 human years. Yet, it is unclear whether this achievement will be transferrable to humans.
As of June 2018, several people have reached milestones in human lifespans:
46 people have reached the age of 115.
19 people have reached the age of 116.
9 people have reached the age of 117.
2 people have lived beyond the age of 117.
Only one person is verified to have lived to 120, and they lived to 122.

reasons: Global thermonuclear war could drastically alter the global economic landscape, potentially affecting the feasibility and attractiveness of large IPOs like Starlink's.
A global thermonuclear war could also impact scientific research and funding, which might delay or accelerate progress in human lifespan enhancement.
The success of a large IPO like Starlink's could influence global economic stability and investment in scientific research, indirectly affecting progress in human lifespan enhancement.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as they all involve significant global events that could impact each other.

P.title: Before 2032, will we see an event precipitated by AI malfunction that causes at least 100 deaths and/or at least $1B 2021 USD in economic damage?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves as Yes if, before January 1, 2032, there are three credible media reports indicating that there has been one or more events precipitated by AI malfunction which caused either 100+ deaths or $1bn 2021 USD in economic damage.
Multiple incidents stemming from the same source can count for the question to resolve as Yes. To be considered from the same source the incidents must be attributable to a specific flaw or version of an AI. For example, deaths from a prior major version of Tesla’s self-driving car software would not be summed with deaths attributable to later versions.
To count as precipitated by AI malfunction an incident should involve an AI system behaving unexpectedly. An example could be if an AI system autonomously driving cars caused hundreds of deaths which would have been easily avoidable for human drivers, or if an AI system overseeing a hospital system took actions to cause patient deaths as a result of misinterpreting a goal to minimise bed usage.
To be considered easily avoidable an incident must not involve human negligence. For example, if a human is expected to monitor the AI and promptly intervene, a failure to intervene resulting in death or economic damage would not be considered attributable to an AI malfunction unless the AI malfunction was such that a human could not reasonably be expected to prevent it. If, for example, the Boeing MCAS system had been an AI system and there was no possibility for the pilots to override its decision to lower the aeroplane nose, leading to a fatal crash, this would count for resolution.
Deaths or damage caused by an AI's expected and intended behavior will not be included; for example, AIs used to target enemy combatants in war would be excluded, as well as AIs successfully performing a medical treatment as specified, despite the treatment causing harms that the doctors or designers were unaware of. An unexpected malfunction of an AI system used in war leading to collateral damage would qualify for the question to resolve as Yes.
Fine Print
A system should be considered AI if it is widely considered to be AI (e.g. by the credible media reports resolving the question). If this is not sufficiently clear for resolution, then as a secondary criterion, any system using machine learning techniques which has an agentic role in the disaster in question should count for this question.
Economic damage will be considered to be expenses incurred by damage to physical or technological systems or by obstruction of productive output. For example, causing a power outage which leads to economic loss from affected businesses would count, while losing money in an AI-directed investment portfolio would not.
This question will resolve according to Metaculus' sole discretion.
The resolution criteria of this question were updated on May 2, 2023. See this comment for more details.

Q_given_P.title: If there is an AI malfunction causing significant damage before 2032, will there be at least one fatality in India from a nuclear detonation by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: Before January 1, 2032, there are three credible media reports indicating that there has been one or more events precipitated by AI malfunction which caused either 100+ deaths or $1bn 2021 USD in economic damage. Multiple incidents stemming from the same source can count for the question to resolve as Yes. To be considered from the same source the incidents must be attributable to a specific flaw or version of an AI. To count as precipitated by AI malfunction an incident should involve an AI system behaving unexpectedly. Deaths or damage caused by an AI's expected and intended behavior will not be included. A system should be considered AI if it is widely considered to be AI. Economic damage will be considered to be expenses incurred by damage to physical or technological systems or by obstruction of productive output.

Then, will there be at least one fatality in India from an offensive nuclear detonation by January 1, 2030? This is conditional on at least one offensive nuclear detonation occurring anywhere on Earth between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution. An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage). A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Given both an AI malfunction causing significant harm and a nuclear detonation causing fatalities in India, will US labor productivity growth be 2% or above in 2025?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Suppose the following is true: (a) Before 2032, there is an event precipitated by AI malfunction that causes at least 100 deaths and/or at least $1B 2021 USD in economic damage, and (b) If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, there is at least one fatality in India.

Resolution Criteria for (a): This resolves as Yes if, before January 1, 2032, there are three credible media reports indicating that there has been one or more events precipitated by AI malfunction which caused either 100+ deaths or $1bn 2021 USD in economic damage. Multiple incidents stemming from the same source can count for the question to resolve as Yes. To be considered from the same source the incidents must be attributable to a specific flaw or version of an AI. For example, deaths from a prior major version of Tesla’s self-driving car software would not be summed with deaths attributable to later versions. To count as precipitated by AI malfunction an incident should involve an AI system behaving unexpectedly. An example could be if an AI system autonomously driving cars caused hundreds of deaths which would have been easily avoidable for human drivers, or if an AI system overseeing a hospital system took actions to cause patient deaths as a result of misinterpreting a goal to minimise bed usage. To be considered easily avoidable an incident must not involve human negligence. For example, if a human is expected to monitor the AI and promptly intervene, a failure to intervene resulting in death or economic damage would not be considered attributable to an AI malfunction unless the AI malfunction was such that a human could not reasonably be expected to prevent it. If, for example, the Boeing MCAS system had been an AI system and there was no possibility for the pilots to override its decision to lower the aeroplane nose, leading to a fatal crash, this would count for resolution. Deaths or damage caused by an AI's expected and intended behavior will not be included; for example, AIs used to target enemy combatants in war would be excluded, as well as AIs successfully performing a medical treatment as specified, despite the treatment causing harms that the doctors or designers were unaware of. An unexpected malfunction of an AI system used in war leading to collateral damage would qualify for the question to resolve as Yes. A system should be considered AI if it is widely considered to be AI (e.g. by the credible media reports resolving the question). If this is not sufficiently clear for resolution, then as a secondary criterion, any system using machine learning techniques which has an agentic role in the disaster in question should count for this question. Economic damage will be considered to be expenses incurred by damage to physical or technological systems or by obstruction of productive output. For example, causing a power outage which leads to economic loss from affected businesses would count, while losing money in an AI-directed investment portfolio would not. This question will resolve according to Metaculus' sole discretion. The resolution criteria of this question were updated on May 2, 2023. See this comment for more details.

Resolution Criteria for (b): This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous. If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution. For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage). Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins. A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

Then is the annual rate of US labor productivity growth for the year 2025, as measured by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2 percent or above? If Robert D Atkinson is declared the winner of the bet by the Long Now Foundation, then this question resolves positively. If Alberto Forchielli is declared the winner, then this question resolves negatively.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

AND
